etymology.description: pictogram: water flowing; see 水, 川, 𡿧; unrelated to 兪 (> 俞).
etymology.interpretation: Three winding strokes depict the meandering course of streams, conveying the idea of flowing water and waterways. It belongs to the same graphic family as 川 and 𡿧, and any resemblance to 兪/俞 is accidental, not etymological.

examples.chinese: 古籍中可见“巛”字，表示流水与水道(古籍中可見「巛」字，表示流水與水道)。
examples.pinyin: Gǔjí zhōng kějiàn “chuān” zì, biǎoshì liúshuǐ yǔ shuǐdào.
examples.english: In ancient texts, the character “巛” can be found, denoting flowing water and waterways.

examples.chinese: 在某些字里，“巛”作部件，表示与水有关(在某些字裡，「巛」作部件，表示與水有關)。
examples.pinyin: Zài mǒuxiē zì lǐ, “chuān” zuò bùjiàn, biǎoshì yǔ shuǐ yǒuguān.
examples.english: In some characters, “巛” functions as a component indicating a relation to water.

examples.chinese: 现代汉语中多用“川”，而“巛”较少单独使用(現代漢語中多用「川」，而「巛」較少單獨使用)。
examples.pinyin: Xiàndài Hànyǔ zhōng duō yòng “chuān”, ér “chuān” jiào shǎo dāndú shǐyòng.
examples.english: In modern Chinese, “川” is used more often, while “巛” is seldom used independently.
